This species was originally isolated from seawater collected near the coast of South Korea. Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Aquimarina spinulae is closely related to other Aquimarina species, sharing high sequence similarities with them.

Aquimarina spinulae is an oxidase-positive and catalase-positive bacterium. It is capable of hydrolyzing various macromolecules, such as starch, gelatin, and Tween 80, indicating its ability to utilize a range of organic compounds for growth and survival in the marine environment.

The optimal growth conditions for Aquimarina spinulae include a temperature range of 20-30°C and a slightly alkaline pH between 7.0 and 8.0. This species requires sodium ions (Na+) for growth, reflecting its adaptation to the marine ecosystem.

Overall, Aquimarina spinulae is a distinctive member of the genus Aquimarina, contributing to the diversity and ecological roles of bacteria in the marine environment.
